Award.AwardTitle: OK-LSAMP Bridge to the Doctorate - OU - Cohort VI

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Oklahoma Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (OK-LSAMP), through a sub-contract with the University of Oklahoma (OU), proposes to support twelve (12) LSAMP students who have completed baccalaureate degrees to pursue and complete PhD programs in a STEM field. This proposal accords with NSF's goal to increase the number of LSAMP students successfully completing terminal degrees in STEM fields. It gives particular attention to the recruitment and support of Native American, Hispanic, African American, and rural populations from the region including women and first generation college students in addition to a wide range of traditional under-represented groups. The long term goal of this program is to increase the number of under-represented students who complete doctoral degrees in STEM fields at OU. Collaboration between the Bridge to the Doctorate (BD) program and other programs at OU will not only benefit the BD Fellows but also the faculty engaged in research targeted toward promoting diversity in STEM fields.

The BD program will support students academically and professionally, ensuring they build the connections and skills needed to excel and to ensure financial support for students in all years of their doctoral programs. Program activities in support of these objectives include, but are not limited to: (1) mentoring and networking programs across STEM departments; (2) links to other NSF-funded programs; (3) student development workshops and counseling; and (4) enhanced recruitment strategies, newsletters, and community outreach. By addressing the underrepresentation of minorities and women at the graduate level in STEM fields, Oklahoma expects to increase recruitment and retention of these students into faculty, business, and other STEM career areas.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The University of Oklahoma - Norman Campus (OU), a member of the Oklahoma Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (LSAMP-BD), supported thirteen Bridge to the Doctorate fellow recipients with their Cohort VI award, beginning in August 2013.  Fellows were recruited from seven institutional members of the OK LSAMP Alliance, including five predominately undergraduate institutions, and two other Alliances.

The first goal for the Cohort VI award was that "all Fellows would have identified research mentors by the start of year two". All Fellows achieved this milestone by the beginning of their 2nd year in the program. The Fellows matriculated into ten different degree programs on the OU-Norman Campus or the OU Health Science Center campus in Oklahoma City: biochemistry, biomedical engineering, chemical engineering, civil engineering, electrical engineering, geophysics, mathematics, mechanical engineering, microbiology, and radiological science.

Goals Two and Three for Cohort VI are closely related.

2. At least 80% of the Fellows earn PhD degrees

3. Each BD Fellow earns at least one graduate degree in a STEM field

Not only did Fellows have their research mentors selected by their second year, eight Fellows had completed a Master's degree or passed equivalent competency exams in direct-to-PhD programs by the end of their second year. A ninth Fellow completed their MS degree in the fall after their second year, having taken a military leave of absence during their first year. BD Fellows have presented research at regional, national, and international conferences and published in high impact journals in their fields.

At the end of the award period, one Fellow has completed a PhD and five have received MS degrees in their disciplines. Three Fellows matriculated directly to PhD programs and are on track to complete their doctoral degrees in 2017 or 2018. One other Fellow will defend their MS thesis soon and will continue toward a PhD. Although we fell a little short of all BD Fellows earning at least one graduate degree in a STEM field at OU, at last contact, two of the three Fellows who left the program without a post-baccalaureate degree were continuing their education elsewhere. Fellows recruited as first-year graduate students could not be expected to complete a PhD within the award timeframe. However, if all students who are qualified to continue on to the PhD choose to do so, Cohort VI will reach the 80% goal eventually.

Through this LSAMP-BD award, OU accomplished a Broader Impact of contributing significantly to the diversity of graduate degree holding scientists and engineers.  Five Fellows are female, including two returning and parenting students. The Fellows included four students identifying as African-American, six Hispanic, two Native American, and one Pacific Islander. The BD program formed a basis for partnerships and collaborations among the Office of Undergraduate Research, the new Vice-President for University Community, and the Graduate College. Lessons learned from Cohort VI and previous LSAMP BD cohorts are leading to improved practices for recruiting and supporting students of color to STEM graduate programs.
